title: The Accident creator explains how Grenfell Tower disaster led to show’s creation
text:
Jack Thorne wrote about corporate manslaughter following the Grenfell disaster (Picture: PA/Channel 4)

The Accident creator Jack Thorne has spoken about how the Grenfell Tower tragedy shaped the harrowing new Channel 4 drama.

The new four-part series deals with issues of class in times of tragedy and focuses on a Welsh town whose lives are changed forever when a gas explosion rips through a building site, killing teenagers.

Sarah Lancashire leads the cast as mother Polly, whose daughter is lost in the disaster, and who launches a fight for justice in the face of the upper class business responsible for the property developers.

But while the bones of the series and the centre of the story was set, the creation of the show was altered in the light of the Grenfell disaster of 2017, when a central London block of flats went up in flames, killing 71 as elements of the building were highly flammable.

After being approached to dramatise the Grenfell disaster, Thorne refused, explaining to RadioTimes: ‘I didn’t feel like there were the facts in place to look at it properly without hurting an awful lot of people, and doing a television thing of trampling over people’s lives.

‘Not to say that there isn’t a beautiful drama to be made, I just didn’t feel capable of it myself.’

Instead, Thorne opted to use the premise of corporate manslaughter, adding: ‘This is extraordinary that this has happened in our country, when we’re supposed to be people that are capable of looking after each other.’

‘Then this phrase ‘corporate manslaughter’ kept getting thrown around and I didn’t understand it,’ he continued. ‘And then it was looking into that and going, “Okay, how does this work? And what is that, and what is the charge, and how does it stick?” – that was the starting point for the whole thing.’

However, in the case of The Accident as well as Grenfell, finding singular blame is not that simple, and both have a fight on their hands in order to get retribution for the loved ones that they lost.

The Grenfell Tower Inquiry is ongoing, and the flammable cladding that caused the spread of the fire is still prevalent in high rise buildings across London.

It’s believed 14 families who lost their home in the fire are still yet to be given new housing.

The Accident will air Thursday 24 October at 9pm on Channel 4.
